results.title: Our invisible committees
results.creator_credit: National Training Laboratory in Group Development
results.brief_description: The point of view is presented that one of the most important obstacles to group thought and decision-making is the conflict of social pressures which operate within individuals during a meeting. The presentation is in the form of a case study of a typical group made up of representatives from various community organisation, which is holding its initial meeting.

results.title: Our inheritance from the past
results.brief_description: Explains, for American school children, how certain features of modern life have been inherited from the past. Instances the farm cultivator which developed from the ancient plough; the highway and its origin in Roman road-making; the wheel which was introduced in early history. The film also describes how knowledge is passed on either orally, in writing or in print.

results.title: Our inheritance from historic Greece
results.brief_description: Illustrates aspects of modern everyday life which can be traced back to that of the ancient Greeks. Aspects discussed are architecture, dress, ideas such as democracy, word derivations, electricity, zoology, mathematics and botany. Each element is depicted in its present-day use as well as its ancient Greek origin.

results.title: Our house
results.creator_credit: Independent Television Service, Sugar Pictures and Meema Spadola
results.brief_description: This US documentary profiles children in five diverse families as they face the challenges and joys of growing up in gay/lesbian households. An inspiring and warming exploration of what family values really should be about. The five families come from diverse socio-economic, racial and religious backgrounds across the USA.

results.title: Our heritage
results.brief_description: Shows examples of carvings, statuary and sculpture to be found in religious temples and shrines in the Deccan area of Southern India. Hindu, Buddhist, Bravidiah and Muslem architecture are represented.

results.title: Our golden heritage
results.creator_credit: Film Partnership (Vic.) and Australian Dairy Board
results.brief_description: Traces the early methods of making butter, capturing something of the simplicity of Australia’s early history. From here the scene moves to the modern interior of a dairy factory showing buttermakers and packers at work. To conclude, some examples of the ways butter can be used in cooking are shown.

results.title: Our Fragile Wilderness
results.creator_credit: Central Coast Media, Mark Falzon and Michael Edols
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Under southern skies”.
The south-west corner of Western Australia has a relatively undisturbed ecosystem where 85% of the plants grow nowhere else in Australia. Grant Wardell-Johnson, a committed ecologist, guides series presenter, Susie Hanckel, through this region of giant Karri and Jarrah forests and swamps, revealing how the the impact of man’s encroachment on this ecosystem can be gauged by studying certain unique species of frogs in the area.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Central Coast Media, Mark Falzon and Michael Edols

results.title: Our fragile coast
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre and David Hughes
results.brief_description: Examines the twin processes of erosion and deposition along the Victorian coast. These areas include Port Cambell, the Gippsland Lakes, Ninety-Mile Beach, and Port Phillip Bay. Sea-Beach poem by Judith Wright.

results.title: Our food
results.brief_description: Traces the sources and processing of many familiar foods. Shows both the old fashioned and modern ways of raising wheat, making bread, milking cows and separating cream. Includes visits to a spaghetti factory, chicken and egg farm, a dairy, a cheese factory, a potato field, an apple orchard, a fishing trawler, a meat processing plant and a sausage shop. Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Our feathered friends
results.creator_credit: Films Division, Government of India, Ezra Mir and Goopal Datt
results.brief_description: Fascinating birds abound in India. On the water there are storks, spoonbills, ibis, pelicans which are varied as to color, size and the shape of their beaks. Quiet except during the breeding season in contrast to others which chatter constantly, such as seagulls migrating from Europe. The monsoon heralds the mating season, when storks choose partners, court each other with dances and build nests for their young in trees or on the water in the reeds or on mounds, like the flamingoes, whose chicks change color as they grow up far from human habitation.
